positive.review:
Age of Empires III was a very different experience for me. I came into it with years of love for the older titles, especially AOE II, so the shift in style and mechanics took time to adjust to. The gameplay moves away from the classic medieval setting and introduces a new direction with home cities, shipments, and a more scripted feel. It did not give me the same excitement that the earlier games gave, and some parts just did not connect with me the way I hoped.

That said, I still recommend trying it. It is not a bad game at all. It is simply different. Some players enjoy the changes, and some do not. The visuals look great for the time, the animations are smooth, and the setting around the colonial era is interesting. The campaigns are well made and tell good stories. The home city system adds a unique layer of strategy, and if you get into it, the game can be quite addictive.

The reason I still recommend it is that AOE III has its own identity. It is not trying to be AOE II or AOE I. It takes the franchise in a new direction. Some people absolutely love that, and some people prefer the classic style. You may or may not enjoy it, but it is definitely worth trying at least once, especially if you are a fan of the series.

For me, it sits below AOE II, but it is still a solid entry in the franchise and a game that deserves a fair chance.

I've been playing this game back when it was the Asian Dynasties. I was addicted to it helplessly and i've decided to return to that timeless masterpiece after quite some time. I love the stuff that was added over the years and the fact that AoE3 has finaly gotten the attention it deserves. Even if, currently it's getting neglected. 

Some advices:

If youre a AoE2 player, expect the game to differ from what you're used to. You'll essentialy have to learn to play AoE from scratch.  Some things such as gathering resources get done by the vils getting their resources instantly without returning to the TC, it has  trade, monopoly plots and natives with which you can form an alliance with, treasures and of course, the infamous home city where you take upgrades and units for free after some time. Of course, not evertything can be covered here. But expect a vastly different experience when playing AoE3. 

For new players, what i advise is to take it slow. AoE3 is a complex game with complex mechanics and flexible strategy, You'll have to explore the map, to find out the cons and pros of each military unit you'll send to the front. How to build your colony correctly, how to manage your economy, etc etc. It takes time, practise with skirmishes and with the campaign mode which the game comes with, finishing the art of war wouldn't hurt as well. it will help you understand the mechanics of the game well enough so you could increase the difficulty of your games and, potentialy win a game or two online. Just know that it will be a long process. 

And if you're returning after a break like i did? Play some skirmishes and find out the new juicy stuff that was added. You'll come around quickly.

negative.review:
This is not the best that Age of Empires III has to offer.
Sure, it looks nicer, it's got some more content than the retail version, but overall, this is not the way to get the true Age of Empires III experience.

Campaigns from the original game were butchered, especially the ones involving John Black and Chayton Black. Mentions of Kanyenke were haphazardly chopped up to reflect his new name of Kanien, instead of bringing actors back to re-record. Mentions of the word "Iroquois" and "Sioux" were just outright deleted. The entire involvement of Nohnakee in Act II: Ice has been eradicated. Act II: Smoke was almost completely rewritten, removing historical characters and events in favor of even more fantasy.

New and changed civilizations lack the polish and care that went into the originals. To use an original civ as an example, British units that unlock later in the game speak more-modern English than units unlocked earlier; Ensemble in 2007 actually cared to include this detail to reflect the passage of time.
But then look at the United States, where the villagers are voiced by a text-to-speech machine instead of an actual actor. 
Or the revised Iroquois and Sioux, whose villagers (especially female) are voiced by non-actors with terrible delivery that's genuinely painful to listen to. Sure, the dialogue is more accurate to the language, but  
Or the Italians, whose female villagers use masculine nouns to refer to themselves when assigned to gather resources, because nobody involved in that process cared enough to make any attempt to understand how the Italian language works.

And that's before bringing in all the random changes that amount to nothing more than pandering - plantations are now estates, even though most of the civilizations who have access to them did not have the concept of the aristocratic estate. Fire pits became community plazas, but are still used to perform magic and summon units, while villagers tasked to the plaza perform practically no animations. Native civs use tribal marketplaces instead of being able to mine coin directly, but again do not have any substantial animations for working them. Especially egregious is the fact that the Iroquois and Sioux had their voice lines revised entirely, but the Aztecs - a people who no longer exist - were entirely untouched from their original version. Why? Because no Aztecs are alive today to complain, but there are living Iroquois and Sioux.

Many of the changes were dressed up as favoring historical accuracy. 
But then, why not change the Aztecs?
Why is the new flag for the Germans now the flag of the Holy Roman Empire, even though the civ represents the Kingdom of Prussia? Its face is Frederick the Great, Prussian King-Elector, never Holy Roman Emperor.
Why is the new flag for the Russians the tricolor? Sure, the double-headed eagle flag they had in 2007 wasn't historically accurate for Ivan the Terrible either, but the tricolor is now even further outside of his time period.
Why is the capital of the United States in Washington? The personality for the civ is Washington himself, but the home city is a place that did not exist in his lifetime. Campaign variants of the US correctly portrayed the home city as Philadelphia.

Age of Empires III is a great game for sure. This version is also the only way now to play online multiplayer, now that Ensemble Online is dead. It has a lot of good balance changes, but overall, this is not the best version of the game. The best version of the game, especially for campaign-focused play, will always be the 2007 original.

There's a lot that's very good and very fun about this game (I've played past versions and the original release, a lot more than just the 17hrs on record) but there's something just sort of [i]wrong[/i] with the AI in regular skirmish? It's fun to sit down with the homies and fight a bunch of amped up difficulty AI, but in AOEIII:DE, the AI doesn't really [i]fight[/i] you or your army. They will literally march huge columns of troops right by your own attack forces, often letting you get some free volleys in before they decide they should probably fight but even then 2/3rds of them will continue to make a beeline to your base (Or often, a trading post). They aren't particularly smart or clever like AOEII:DE AI, often just hugging your walls and walking along them not fighting and just letting you blast away.

If you're not doing mostly vs. AI it's an easy recommendation, especially the campaign/scenarios where the AI [i]will[/i] fight you because they're scripted to do it. But for my use case the AI just doesn't participate in actually fighting, instead beelining at your town center or a trade post (even if it's in your backline) and just letting you whittle down their troops without really doing anything about it.

Mentions of Kanyenke were haphazardly chopped up to reflect his new name of Kanien, instead of bringing actors back to re-record. Mentions of the word "Iroquois" and "Sioux" were just outright deleted. The entire involvement of Nohnakee in Act II: Ice has been eradicated. Act II: Smoke was almost completely rewritten, removing historical characters and events in favor of even more fantasy.

New and changed civilizations lack the polish and care that went into the originals. To use an original civ as an example, British units that unlock later in the game speak more-modern English than units unlocked earlier; Ensemble in 2007 actually cared to include this detail to reflect the passage of time.
But then look at the United States, where the villagers are voiced by a text-to-speech machine instead of an actual actor. 
Or the revised Iroquois and Sioux, whose villagers (especially female) are voiced by non-actors with terrible delivery that's genuinely painful to listen to. Sure, the dialogue is more accurate to the language, but  
Or the Italians, whose female villagers use masculine nouns to refer to themselves when assigned to gather resources, because nobody involved in that process cared enough to make any attempt to understand how the Italian language works.

And that's before bringing in all the random changes that amount to nothing more than pandering - plantations are now estates, even though most of the civilizations who have access to them did not have the concept of the aristocratic estate. Fire pits became community plazas, but are still used to perform magic and summon units, while villagers tasked to the plaza perform practically no animations. Native civs use tribal marketplaces instead of being able to mine coin directly, but again do not have any substantial animations for working them. Especially egregious is the fact that the Iroquois and Sioux had their voice lines revised entirely, but the Aztecs - a people who no longer exist - were entirely untouched from their original version. Why? Because no Aztecs are alive today to complain, but there are living Iroquois and Sioux.

Many of the changes were dressed up as favoring historical accuracy. 
But then, why not change the Aztecs?
Why is the new flag for the Germans now the flag of the Holy Roman Empire, even though the civ represents the Kingdom of Prussia? Its face is Frederick the Great, Prussian King-Elector, never Holy Roman Emperor.
Why is the new flag for the Russians the tricolor? Sure, the double-headed eagle flag they had in 2007 wasn't historically accurate for Ivan the Terrible either, but the tricolor is now even further outside of his time period.
Why is the capital of the United States in Washington? The personality for the civ is Washington himself, but the home city is a place that did not exist in his lifetime. Campaign variants of the US correctly portrayed the home city as Philadelphia.

Age of Empires III is a great game for sure. This version is also the only way now to play online multiplayer, now that Ensemble Online is dead. There's a lot that's very good and very fun about this game (I've played past versions and the original release, a lot more than just the 17hrs on record) but there's something just sort of [i]wrong[/i] with the AI in regular skirmish? It's fun to sit down with the homies and fight a bunch of amped up difficulty AI, but in AOEIII:DE, the AI doesn't really [i]fight[/i] you or your army. They will literally march huge columns of troops right by your own attack forces, often letting you get some free volleys in before they decide they should probably fight but even then 2/3rds of them will continue to make a beeline to your base (Or often, a trading post). They aren't particularly smart or clever like AOEII:DE AI, often just hugging your walls and walking along them not fighting and just letting you blast away.

If you're not doing mostly vs. AI it's an easy recommendation, especially the campaign/scenarios where the AI [i]will[/i] fight you because they're scripted to do it. But for my use case the AI just doesn't participate in actually fighting, instead beelining at your town center or a trade post (even if it's in your backline) and just letting you whittle down their troops without really doing anything about it.
